Kalev Pehme has been fired as editor of Chess Life

ldc_scope.charseq: Kalev Pehme has been fired as editor of Chess Life by Beatriz Marinello

extent.charseq: Kalev Pehme did not deserve to be fired

ldc_scope.charseq: Kalev Pehme did not deserve to be fired
Sam Sloan writes that Beatriz Marinello has fired Kalev Pehme
I don't doubt that she wanted him gone, but the editor was fired by the Board in a 5 to 2 with Schultz and Brady voting against
One assumes that Tim Hanke's vote to fire means he will not be working for Chess Life in any capacity for at least two years after he is off the Board, when he might make a fine editor
Here is my read on his firing: he was not fired because the politically correct crowd didn't like his writing about women players, nor was he fired because Paul Truong and Susan Polgar wanted him out

extent.charseq: he fired because the average reader disliked the magazine, which looked fine, arrived on time (for the first time in many a moon) and kept improving with each issue

ldc_scope.charseq: Nor, I think, was he fired because the average reader disliked the magazine, which looked fine, arrived on time (for the first time in many a moon) and kept improving with each issue

extent.charseq: the magazine, which looked fine, arrived on time (for the first time in many a moon) and kept improving with each issue
he got the ax because the scholastic people wanted him out, which marks a watershed in the history of this Federation

ldc_scope.charseq: I think he got the ax because the scholastic people wanted him out, which marks a watershed in the history of this Federation's affairs: for the first time a membership faction as opposed purely to a political faction (though there was that, too) has prevailed in the firing of an editor

Laugh - I knew this was the plan a good while ago, not soon after he was hired

I tested the waters in the Fall when I noticed a retraction from those who had interviewed him and proposed him on the basis of personal meetings, who were now politically diffident, saying nothing in 1,000 words on the subject
